scenario:
Micron Technology (MU) reported earnings for its first quarter of fiscal 2025, with a top line soaring 85% year over year, driven by a growing data center business. The company's profit margins are widening, with a net income of $1.9 billion, a significant improvement from a loss of $1.2 billion in the same period in 2023. However, shares have cratered by 18% since the earnings report, with the current share price of $85 close to a 52-week low.

The sell-off was caused by Micron's guidance for revenue of $7.9 billion (plus or minus $200 million) and earnings per share (EPS) of $1.23 (plus or minus $0.10), which was perceived as weaker than expected by the investment community. The company's EPS guidance was also lower than the consensus estimate among analysts.

Despite the weaker-than-expected forecast, the long-term thesis for Micron remains intact, with the company expected to grow revenue by 36% year over year and accelerate its earnings power by nearly double that rate. Micron's position in the chip realm is also strong, with the company developing storage and memory chips that are expected to be in high demand due to the AI revolution.

Micron's valuation makes it a tempting buy, with a forward price-to-earnings (P/E) multiple of 12, which is hovering around its lowest levels in a year and pales in comparison to its peers. The sell-off in Micron stock is seen as an opportunity to scoop up shares and prepare to hold for the long run.

AMD, a peer company, is mentioned as one of the companies that will be impacted by the growing demand for storage and memory chips due to the AI revolution.
